title: Equipment
description: Equipment requirements including food-contact surface standards, equipment cleanliness, proper construction and maintenance, calibration of measuring devices, and prevention of contamination from equipment

requirements.text: Are food contact equipment surfaces free of flaking paint, corrosion, rust and other unhygienic materials (e.g., tape, string, cardboard, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Food contact equipment surfaces must be free of flaking paint, corrosion, and rust
Unhygienic repair materials such as tape, string, or cardboard are prohibited
Regular inspections must detect surface deterioration
Damaged surfaces must be repaired with food-grade materials
Equipment must be removed from service until properly repaired
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly food contact surface condition inspections, quarterly preventive maintenance assessments
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily pre-operational equipment inspections, immediate removal from service if deterioration detected

requirements.text: Are non-food contact equipment surfaces free of flaking paint, corrosion, rust and other unhygienic materials (e.g., tape, string, cardboard, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Non-food contact equipment surfaces must be maintained free of flaking paint, corrosion, and rust
Unhygienic repairs on non-food contact surfaces must be corrected
Maintenance must prevent contamination transfer to food contact areas
Regular inspections must include non-food contact surfaces
Repairs must use appropriate permanent materials
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly non-food contact surface inspections, annual comprehensive equipment condition assessment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly visual inspections, immediate repair of deteriorating surfaces

requirements.text: Does food contact equipment design, placement, and condition (e.g., smooth surfaces, smooth weld seams, non-toxic materials, corrosion-resistant, non-porous, non-absorbent) facilitate effective cleaning and maintenance?
mandatoryStatements: Food contact equipment must be designed with smooth, non-porous, non-absorbent surfaces
Weld seams must be smooth and polished
Equipment must be constructed of non-toxic, corrosion-resistant materials
Design must facilitate effective cleaning and maintenance
Equipment placement must allow access for cleaning
Sanitary design principles must be evaluated for new equipment purchases
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual equipment design and cleanability assessment, evaluation of new equipment against sanitary design criteria
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Cleaning effectiveness verification through ATP testing or environmental monitoring, immediate design modifications if cleaning proves inadequate

requirements.text: Are thermometers (independent of thermostat probes) present in all coolers and freezers?
mandatoryStatements: Independent thermometers separate from thermostat controls must be in all coolers and freezers
Thermometers must be calibrated and accurate
Thermometers must be positioned in warmest spots for representative readings
Thermometers must be easily readable without opening doors
Temperature monitoring logs must be maintained
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly thermometer calibration verification, annual review of thermometer placement adequacy
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily temperature readings from independent thermometers, immediate response to out-of-range temperatures

requirements.text: Are all thermometers non-glass and non-mercury?
mandatoryStatements: All thermometers must be non-glass and non-mercury types
Digital or spirit-filled (alcohol-based) thermometers required
Glass and mercury thermometers must be removed from facility
Purchasing specifications must prohibit glass and mercury thermometers
Regular audits must verify no prohibited thermometers present
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual facility audit for glass and mercury thermometers, verification during equipment purchases
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Immediate removal and replacement if glass or mercury thermometers discovered

mandatoryStatements: Food contact equipment surfaces must be free of flaking paint, corrosion, rust, and any unhygienic repair materials such as tape, string, or cardboard that could contaminate products or harbor pathogens

Non-food contact equipment surfaces must also be maintained free of flaking paint, corrosion, rust, and unhygienic materials to prevent contamination through transfer or particulate fallout onto food contact areas

Food contact equipment must be designed with smooth, non-porous, non-absorbent surfaces, smooth weld seams, and constructed of non-toxic, corrosion-resistant materials that can be effectively cleaned and sanitized

Independent thermometers separate from thermostat control probes must be installed in all refrigerated coolers and freezers to verify actual product storage temperatures and detect equipment malfunctions
All thermometers used in food production and storage areas must be non-glass and non-mercury types to eliminate physical and chemical contamination risks from breakage
capaInject: When food contact surfaces show flaking paint, corrosion, or rust, immediately remove equipment from service, assess extent of product contamination risk, strip and re-coat surfaces with food-grade epoxy or paint, replace corroded components with stainless steel or food-grade alternatives, and establish preventive maintenance inspection schedules to detect deterioration before failure

If unhygienic repair materials (tape, string, cardboard) are found on equipment, immediately remove all temporary repairs, replace with proper food-grade materials and permanent repair methods, establish policies prohibiting use of non-approved materials, provide proper repair supplies and training to maintenance personnel, and conduct facility-wide audits for similar issues

For non-food contact equipment showing deterioration, immediately assess contamination transfer risk to food contact areas, prioritize repairs based on proximity to food products, establish preventive maintenance schedules for all equipment, implement color-coded tools and parts designation (food vs. non-food contact), and maintain equipment condition logs

When equipment design impedes effective cleaning, evaluate equipment for replacement or modification, install removable panels or access ports to reach difficult areas, consider equipment with tool-free disassembly capability, establish enhanced cleaning procedures with verification requirements, and evaluate new equipment purchases against sanitary design criteria

If coolers or freezers lack independent thermometers, immediately install calibrated thermometers in representative locations (warmest spots), position for easy reading without opening doors, establish temperature monitoring logs with defined frequency and acceptance criteria, implement alarm systems for out-of-range temperatures, and verify thermostat accuracy against independent measurements

Upon discovering glass or mercury thermometers, immediately remove them from service, replace with digital or spirit-filled (alcohol-based) thermometers, conduct facility audit to identify and remove all glass and mercury devices, establish purchasing specifications prohibiting glass and mercury, and provide training on physical and chemical hazard prevention
traceabilityInject: Maintain equipment condition inspection records documenting inspection date, equipment identification, findings of paint condition, corrosion, rust, or unauthorized repairs, corrective actions taken, and verification of repair completion

Keep equipment maintenance logs showing preventive maintenance schedules, work performed, parts replaced, cleaning procedures, and equipment condition assessment with photographic documentation of repairs

Document equipment design and sanitary evaluation records including sanitary design criteria assessment, cleaning validation studies, equipment modification records, and new equipment purchase justifications demonstrating improved cleanability

Retain thermometer calibration records showing calibration method (ice bath, boiling water, or certified standards), calibration frequency, results, adjustments made, and replacement dates for failed thermometers

Maintain temperature monitoring logs for all coolers and freezers documenting daily temperature readings, alarm events, out-of-specification occurrences, corrective actions, and equipment service records
Keep equipment inventory records identifying all food contact and non-food contact equipment with unique identifiers, materials of construction, cleaning requirements, and maintenance schedules

Document glass and mercury elimination audits showing locations inspected, devices found and removed, replacement devices installed, and ongoing verification that prohibited items remain excluded from facility
micro_inject: Flaking paint from food contact surfaces can harbor Listeria monocytogenes and other pathogenic bacteria in crevices and chips; paint particles that detach become foreign material contamination and potential vehicles for pathogen transfer to products

Rust and corrosion create pitted surfaces with increased surface area and crevices that provide ideal harborage for bacterial biofilm formation; Listeria biofilms in corrosion pits can persist for years despite cleaning and resist sanitizer penetration

Porous or absorbent food contact materials can absorb product residues, moisture, and bacteria into the material matrix where they cannot be reached by cleaning; subsequent release of trapped bacteria contaminates future product batches

Rough surfaces, including coarse weld seams and damaged equipment surfaces, provide increased surface area for bacterial attachment and biofilm development; cleanability decreases exponentially as surface roughness increases beyond critical thresholds

Unhygienic repair materials like tape, cardboard, or string used on equipment provide nutrients, moisture retention, and protected environments for bacterial growth; these materials cannot be effectively cleaned or sanitized and continuously shed particles and bacteria

Temperature monitoring failures that go undetected due to lack of independent thermometers can result in extended time-temperature abuse allowing psychrotrophic pathogens like Listeria monocytogenes to multiply to dangerous levels before detection

Glass thermometer breakage in refrigeration units or processing equipment can contaminate large quantities of product with glass fragments and potentially toxic mercury; glass shards may not be detected by metal detectors or x-ray equipment

Mercury from broken thermometers is highly toxic and can vaporize at room temperature; mercury contamination in food facilities is extremely difficult to remediate and may require extensive facility closure, decontamination, and product destruction
